member.name: T:TVA.ISupportLifecycle
member.summary: Specifies that this object provides support for performing tasks during the key stages of object lifecycle.

member.name: M:TVA.ISupportLifecycle.Initialize
member.summary: Initializes the state of the object.
member.remarks: Typical implementation of should allow the object state to be initialized only once. should be called automatically from one or more key entry points of the object. For example, if the object is a and it implements the interface then should be called from the method so that the object gets initialized automatically when consumed through the IDE designer surface. In addition to this should also be called from key or mandatory methods of the object, like 'Start()' or 'Connect()', so that the object gets initialized even when not consumed through the IDE designer surface.

member.name: P:TVA.ISupportLifecycle.Enabled
member.summary: Gets or sets a boolean value that indicates whether the object is enabled.
member.remarks: Typical implementation of should suspend the internal processing when the object is disabled and resume processing when the object is enabled.

member.name: M:TVA.Units.Time.ToString(System.Int32,System.String[])
member.summary: Converts the value into a textual representation of years, days, hours, minutes and seconds with the specified number of fractional digits given string array of time names.
member.param: Number of fractional digits to display for seconds.
Time names array to use during textual conversion.

remarks.para: Set second precision to -1 to suppress seconds display.

array needs one string entry for each of the following names:
"Year", "Years", "Day", "Days", "Hour", "Hours", "Minute", "Minutes", "Second", "Seconds", "Less Than 60 Seconds", "0 Seconds".

member.returns: The string representation of the value of this instance, consisting of the number of years, days, hours, minutes and seconds represented by this value.

member.name: M:TVA.Configuration.IniSettingsBase.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class for the application's INI file.
member.param: Name of INI file to use for accessing settings.
Name of default section to use to get and set settings from INI file.
Determines if category attributes will be used for section names.
Assigns flag that determines if is required to exist before a field or property is serialized to the INI file.
member.remarks: If is false, all settings will be placed in section labeled by the value; otherwise, if a exists on a field or property then the member value will serialized into the INI file in a section labeled the same as the value and if the attribute doesn't exist the member value will serialized into the section labeled by the value.

member.name: M:TVA.Configuration.IniSettingsBase.#ctor(TVA.Interop.IniFile,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class for the application's INI file.
member.param: INI file to use for accessing settings.
Name of default section to use to get and set settings from INI file.
Determines if category attributes will be used for section names.
Assigns flag that determines if is required to exist before a field or property is serialized to the INI file.
Determines if method should be called from constructor.

remarks.para: If is false, all settings will be placed in section labeled by the value; otherwise, if a exists on a field or property then the member value will serialized into the INI file in a section labeled the same as the value and if the attribute doesn't exist the member value will serialized into the section labeled by the value.

Note that some .NET languages (e.g., Visual Basic) will not initialize member elements before call to constuctor, in this case should be set to false, then the method should be called manually after all properties have been initialized. Alternately, consider using the on the fields or properties and this will be used to initialize the values.

member.name: P:TVA.ByteEncoding.Hexadecimal
member.summary: Handles encoding and decoding of a byte buffer into a hexadecimal-based presentation format.

member.name: P:TVA.ByteEncoding.Decimal
member.summary: Handles encoding and decoding of a byte buffer into an integer-based presentation format.

member.name: P:TVA.ByteEncoding.BigEndianBinary
member.summary: Handles encoding and decoding of a byte buffer into a big-endian binary (i.e., 0 and 1's) based presentation format.
member.remarks: Although endianness is typically used in the context of byte order (see to handle byte order swapping), this property allows you visualize "bits" in big-endian order, right-to-left. Note that bits are normally stored in the same order as their bytes.).

member.name: P:TVA.ByteEncoding.LittleEndianBinary
member.summary: Handles encoding and decoding of a byte buffer into a little-endian binary (i.e., 0 and 1's) based presentation format.
member.remarks: Although endianness is typically used in the context of byte order (see to handle byte order swapping), this property allows you visualize "bits" in little-endian order, left-to-right. Note that bits are normally stored in the same order as their bytes.

member.name: P:TVA.ByteEncoding.Base64

member.name: T:TVA.BitwiseCast
member.summary: Defines specialized bitwise integer data type conversion functions
member.remarks: This class allows for proper bitwise casting between signed and unsigned integers. It may be most useful in languages that do not allow override of numerical overflow checks. For example, C# provides an "unchecked" keyword to allow for bitwise casting, but VB.NET does not.

member.name: M:TVA.BitwiseCast.ToInt16(System.UInt16)
member.summary: Performs proper bitwise conversion between unsigned and signed value

remarks.para: This function is useful because Convert.ToInt16 will throw an OverflowException for values greater than Int16.MaxValue.
For example, this function correctly converts unsigned 16-bit integer 65535 (i.e., UInt16.MaxValue) to signed 16-bit integer -1.

member.param: Unsigned short that is passed in to be converted to a signed short.
member.returns: The converted short value.

member.name: M:TVA.BitwiseCast.ToInt24(TVA.UInt24)
member.summary: Performs proper bitwise conversion between unsigned and signed value

remarks.para: This function is useful because CType(n, Int24) will throw an OverflowException for values greater than Int24.MaxValue.
For example, this function correctly converts unsigned 24-bit integer 16777215 (i.e., UInt24.MaxValue) to signed 24-bit integer -1.

member.param: Unsigned UInt24 that is passed in to be converted to a signed Int24.
member.returns: The Int24 value.

member.name: M:TVA.BitwiseCast.ToInt32(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Performs proper bitwise conversion between unsigned and signed value

remarks.para: This function is useful because Convert.ToInt32 will throw an OverflowException for values greater than Int32.MaxValue.
For example, this function correctly converts unsigned 32-bit integer 4294967295 (i.e., UInt32.MaxValue) to signed 32-bit integer -1.

member.param: Unsigned integer that is passed in to be converted to a signed Int32.
member.returns: The int value.

member.name: M:TVA.BitwiseCast.ToInt64(System.UInt64)
member.summary: Performs proper bitwise conversion between unsigned and signed value

remarks.para: This function is useful because Convert.ToInt64 will throw an OverflowException for values greater than Int64.MaxValue.
For example, this function correctly converts unsigned 64-bit integer 18446744073709551615 (i.e., UInt64.MaxValue) to signed 64-bit integer -1.

member.param: Unsigned integer that is passed in to be converted to a long.
member.returns: The long value.

member.name: M:TVA.BitwiseCast.ToUInt16(System.Int16)
member.summary: Performs proper bitwise conversion between signed and unsigned value

remarks.para: This function is useful because Convert.ToUInt16 will throw an OverflowException for values less than zero.
For example, this function correctly converts signed 16-bit integer -32768 (i.e., Int16.MinValue) to unsigned 16-bit integer 32768.

member.param: Signed integer that is passed in to be converted to an unsigned short.
member.returns: The unsigned short value.

member.name: M:TVA.BitwiseCast.ToUInt24(TVA.Int24)
member.summary: Performs proper bitwise conversion between signed and unsigned value

remarks.para: This function is useful because CType(n, UInt24) will throw an OverflowException for values less than zero.
For example, this function correctly converts signed 24-bit integer -8388608 (i.e., Int24.MinValue) to unsigned 24-bit integer 8388608.

member.param: Signed integer that is passed in to be converted to an unsigned integer.
member.returns: The unsigned integer value.

member.name: M:TVA.BitwiseCast.ToUInt32(System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs proper bitwise conversion between signed and unsigned value

remarks.para: This function is useful because Convert.ToUInt32 will throw an OverflowException for values less than zero.
For example, this function correctly converts signed 32-bit integer -2147483648 (i.e., Int32.MinValue) to unsigned 32-bit integer 2147483648.

member.param: Signed integer that is passed in to be converted to an unsigned integer.
member.returns: The unsigned integer value.

member.name: M:TVA.BitwiseCast.ToUInt64(System.Int64)
member.summary: Performs proper bitwise conversion between signed and unsigned value

remarks.para: This function is useful because Convert.ToUInt64 will throw an OverflowException for values less than zero.
For example, this function correctly converts signed 64-bit integer -9223372036854775808 (i.e., Int64.MinValue) to unsigned 64-bit integer 9223372036854775808.

member.param: Signed integer that is passed in to be converted to an unsigned long.
member.returns: The unsigned long value.

member.name: M:TVA.PrecisionTimer.SetMinimumTimerResolution(System.Int32)
member.summary: Requests a minimum resolution for periodic timers such as the .
member.param: Minimum timer resolution, in milliseconds, for the application. A lower value specifies a higher (more accurate) resolution.
member.remarks: Call this function immediately before using the and call immediately after you are finished using the PrecisionTimer. You must match each call to with a call to ClearMinimumTimerResolution specifying the same minimum resolution in both calls. An application can make multiple ClearMinimumTimerResolution calls as long as each call is matched with a call to ClearMinimumTimerResolution. This function affects a global Windows setting. Windows uses the lowest value (that is, highest resolution) requested by any process. Setting a higher resolution can improve the accuracy of time-out intervals in wait functions. However, it can also reduce overall system performance, because the thread scheduler switches tasks more often. High resolutions can also prevent the CPU power management system from entering power-saving modes. See timeBeginPeriod Windows API for more information.

member.name: M:TVA.PrecisionTimer.ClearMinimumTimerResolution(System.Int32)
member.summary: Clears a previously set minimum timer resolution established using .
member.param: Minimum timer resolution specified in the previous call to the function.
member.remarks: Call this function immediately after you are finished using the . You must match each call to with a call to , specifying the same minimum resolution in both calls. An application can make multiple SetMinimumTimerResolution calls as long as each call is matched with a call to ClearMinimumTimerResolution.

member.remarks: The resolution is in milliseconds. The resolution increases with smaller values; a resolution of 0 indicates periodic events should occur with the greatest possible accuracy. To reduce system overhead, however, you should use the maximum value appropriate for your application.

member.name: P:TVA.PrecisionTimer.UtcNow
member.summary: Gets a high-resolution value of the current time on this computer, expressed in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

remarks.para: This shared property provides a way to get a value that exhibits the relative precision of , and the absolute accuracy of .

This property is useful for obtaining high-resolution accuarate timestamps for events that occur in the "sub-second" world (e.g., timestamping events happening hundreds or thousands of times per second). Note that the normal property has a maximum resolution of ~16 milliseconds.

This property is useful for obtaining high-resolution accuarate timestamps for events that occur in the "sub-second" world (e.g., timestamping events happening hundreds or thousands of times per second). Note that the normal property has a maximum resolution of ~16 milliseconds.

member.name: T:TVA.NtpTimeTag
member.summary: Represents a standard Network Time Protocol (NTP) timetag.
member.remarks: As recommended by RFC-2030, all NTP timestamps earlier than 3h 14m 08s UTC on 20 January 1968 are reckoned from 6h 28m 16s UTC on 7 February 2036. This gives the class a functioning range of 1968-01-20 03:14:08 to 2104-02-26 09:42:23.

member.name: F:TVA.Media.DataFormatSubType.PCM
member.summary: Standard pulse-code modulation audio format
member.remarks: PCM (Pulse Code Modulation) is a common method of storing and transmitting uncompressed digital audio. Since it is a generic format, it can be read by most audio applicationssimilar to the way a plain text file can be read by any word-processing program. PCM is used by Audio CDs and digital audio tapes (DATs). PCM is also a very common format for AIFF and WAV files.

member.name: F:TVA.Media.DataFormatSubType.ADPCM
member.summary: Adpative differential pulse-code modulation encoding algorithm

member.name: F:TVA.Media.DataFormatSubType.IeeeFloat
member.summary: Floating point PCM encoding algorithm

member.name: F:TVA.Media.DataFormatSubType.DRM
member.summary: Digital Rights Management encoded format (for digital-audio content protected by Microsoft DRM).

member.name: F:TVA.Media.DataFormatSubType.ALaw
member.summary: A-law encoding algorithm (used in Europe and the rest of the world)

member.name: F:TVA.Media.DataFormatSubType.MuLaw
member.summary: -law encoding algorithm (used in North America and Japan)

member.name: F:TVA.Media.DataFormatSubType.Mpeg
member.summary: MPEG Audio is a family of open standards for compressed audio that includes MP2, MP3 and AAC.

member.name: F:TVA.Media.DataFormatSubType.Analog
member.summary: Analog sub-format.

member.name: T:TVA.Configuration.RegistrySettingsBase
member.summary: Represents the base class for application settings that are synchronized to the registry.

remarks.para:
In order to make custom types serializable for the registry, implement a for the type.
See MSDN for details.

member.name: M:TVA.Configuration.RegistrySettingsBase.#ctor(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class for the application's registry based settings.
member.param: Defines the root registry path used to access settings in the registry (e.g., "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\\Software\\My Company\\My Product\\").
Defines the name of default key used to access settings in the registry (e.g., "General Settings").

member.name: M:TVA.Configuration.RegistrySettingsBase.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class for the application's registry based settings.
member.param: Defines the root registry path used to access settings in the registry (e.g., "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\\Software\\My Company\\My Product\\").
Defines the name of default key used to access settings in the registry (e.g., "General Settings").
Determines if category attributes will be used for the registry key names.
Assigns flag that determines if is required to exist before a field or property is serialized to the registry.
Determines if method should be called from constructor.

remarks.para: If is false, all settings will be placed in section labeled by the value; otherwise, if a exists on a field or property then the member value will serialized into the registry in a section labeled the same as the value and if the attribute doesn't exist the member value will serialized into the section labeled by the value.

Note that some .NET languages (e.g., Visual Basic) will not initialize member elements before call to constuctor, in this case should be set to false, then the method should be called manually after all properties have been initialized. Alternately, consider using the on the fields or properties and this will be used to initialize the values.

Setting value.

member.name: P:TVA.Configuration.RegistrySettingsBase.UseCategoryAttributes
member.summary: Gets or sets value that determines whether a applied to a field or property will be used for the registry key names.
member.remarks: If is false, all settings will be placed in section labeled by the value; otherwise, if a exists on a field or property then the member value will serialized into the registry in a section labeled the same as the value and if the attribute doesn't exist the member value will stored in the registry key identified by the value.

member.name: P:TVA.Configuration.EncryptSettingAttribute.PrivateKey
member.summary: Gets or sets optional encryption key that will be used on a setting for added security.
member.remarks: This key is not the actual key used for encryption, it is used for hash lookup of the actual AES key. If this key is not specified, the property name will be used for the hash lookup.

member.name: T:TVA.Interop.VBArrayDescriptor
member.summary: Represents an old style Visual Basic array descriptor.
member.remarks: This class is used to mimic the binary array descriptor used when an array is serialized into a file using older Visual Basic applications (VB 6 and prior), this way old VB apps can still deserialize an array stored in a file written by a .NET application and vice versa.

member.name: M:TVA.Units.Voltage.TryParse(System.String,TVA.Units.Voltage@)
member.summary: Converts the string representation of a number to its equivalent. A return value indicates whether the conversion succeeded or failed.
member.param: A string containing a number to convert.

When this method returns, contains the value equivalent to the number contained in s, if the conversion succeeded, or zero if the conversion failed. member.name: T:TVA.Parsing.MultiSourceFrameImageParserBase`3
member.summary: This class defines a basic implementation of parsing functionality suitable for automating the parsing of multiple binary data streams, each represented as frames with common headers and returning the parsed data via an event.

remarks.para: This class is more specific than the in that it can automate the parsing of a particular protocol that is formatted as a series of frames that have a common method of identification. Automation of type creation occurs by loading implementations of common types that implement the interface. The common method of identification is handled by creating a class derived from the which primarily includes a TypeID property, but also should include any state information needed to parse a particular frame if necessary. Derived classes override the method in order to parse the from a provided binary image.

member.typeparam: Type of identifier for the data source.
Type of identifier used to distinguish output types.
Type of the interface or class used to represent outputs.

member.name: T:TVA.Parsing.FrameImageParserBase`2
member.summary: This class defines a basic implementation of parsing functionality suitable for automating the parsing of a binary data stream represented as frames with common headers and returning the parsed data via an event.

remarks.para: This parser is designed as a write-only stream such that data can come from any source.

This class is more specific than the in that it can automate the parsing of a particular protocol that is formatted as a series of frames that have a common method of identification. Automation of type creation occurs by loading implementations of common types that implement the interface. The common method of identification is handled by creating a class derived from the which primarily includes a TypeID property, but also should include any state information needed to parse a particular frame if necessary. Derived classes simply override the function in order to parse the from a provided binary image.

member.typeparam: Type of identifier used to distinguish output types.
Type of the interface or class used to represent outputs.

member.name: M:TVA.Parsing.BinaryImageParserBase.ParseFrame(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Protocol specific frame parsing algorithm.
member.param: Buffer containing data to parse.
Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The length of the data that was parsed.

remarks.para: Implementors can choose to focus on parsing a single frame in the buffer even if there are other frames available in the buffer. Base class will continue to move through buffer on behalf of derived class until all the buffer has been processed. Just return the total amount of data was parsed and the remaining unparsed will be prepended to next received buffer.

Derived implementations should return an integer value that represents the length of the data that was parsed, and zero if not enough data was able to be parsed. Note that exceptions are expensive when parsing fast moving streaming data and a good coding practice for implementations of this method will be to not throw an exception when there is not enough data to parse the data, instead check the property to insure there is enough data in buffer to represent the desired image. If there is not enough data to represent the image return zero and the base class will prepend buffer onto next incoming set of data.

Because of the expense incurred when an exception is thrown, any exceptions encounted in the derived implementations of this method will cause the current data buffer to be discarded and a event to be raised. Doing this prevents exceptions from being thrown repeatedly for the same data. If your code implementation recognizes a malformed image, raise a custom event to indicate this instead of throwing as exception and keep moving through the buffer.

member.name: M:TVA.Parsing.FrameImageParserBase`2.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Buffer containing data to parse.
Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.

member.name: M:TVA.Parsing.MultiSourceFrameImageParserBase`3.Flush
member.summary: Clears all buffers for this stream and causes any buffered data to be parsed immediately.

remarks.para: If the user has called method, this method will process all remaining buffers on the calling thread until all queued buffers have been parsed - the will then be automatically stopped. This method is typically called on shutdown to make sure any remaining queued buffers get parsed before the class instance is destructed.

It is possible for items to be queued while the flush is executing. The flush will continue to parse buffers as quickly as possible until the internal buffer queue is empty. Unless the user stops queueing data to be parsed (i.e. calling the method), the flush call may never return (not a happy situtation on shutdown).
The does not clear queue prior to destruction. If the user fails to call this method before the class is destructed, there may be data that remains unparsed in the internal buffer.

member.name: M:TVA.Parsing.MultiSourceFrameImageParserBase`3.CreateBufferQueue
member.summary: Creates the internal buffer queue.

remarks.para: This method is virtual to allow derived classes to customize the style of processing queue used when consumers choose to implement an internal buffer queue. Default type is a real-time queue with the default settings. When overriding, use the method for the ) item processing delegate.

Note that current design only supports synchronous parsing - consumer overriding this method to return an asynchronous (i.e., multi-threaded) process queue will need to redesign the processing delegate.

member.returns: New internal buffer processing queue (i.e., a new ).

member.name: T:TVA.Media.SampleRate
member.summary: Typical samples rates supported by wave files.

remarks.para: Quantization of the analog waveform, or signal, is a real-time process operating over a continuous time-period which produces a stream of digital values. In order for the process to work you must define the rate at which new digital values are measured, or sampled, from the analog signal. The rate at which new values are measured is called the sampling rate (a.k.a., the sampling frequency).

Audio based Compact Discs use a sampling rate of 44,100 Hz; this means the the Nyquist frequency is 22,050 Hz (i.e., the upper bound on the highest frequency that the digital data can clearly represent without aliasing). This sample rate selection was no accident as the range of hearing for a healthy young person is approximately 20 to 20,000 Hz.
In plain English, higher sampling rates will equate to higher quality sound reproduction but anything above 44,100 Hz will not be perceived as better quality by normal human beings.

member.name: F:TVA.Media.SampleRate.Hz8000
member.summary: 8000 samples per second

member.summary: 12000 samples per second

member.summary: 16000 samples per second

member.summary: 22050 samples per second

member.summary: 24000 samples per second

member.name: F:TVA.Media.SampleRate.Hz32000
member.summary: 32000 samples per second

member.name: F:TVA.Media.SampleRate.Hz44100
member.summary: 44100 samples per second
member.remarks: This is the standard setting for CD audio quality

member.name: F:TVA.Media.SampleRate.Hz48000
member.summary: 48000 samples per second

member.name: T:TVA.Media.BitsPerSample
member.summary: Typical bit sizes supported by wave files.
member.remarks:
Strictly speaking, bits-per-sample describes the total number of bits used to encode the amplitude (or volume) of a sampled signal. The following table describes a few typical bit ranges and their possible resolution:
Bit range Resolution
8-bits (1 Byte) 0 to 255
16-bits (2 Bytes) -32,768 to 32,767
24-bits (3 Bytes) -8,388,608 to 8,388,607
32-bits (4 Bytes) -2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647
The net result is that more bits you use, the more resolution you can achieve in amplitude; hence more bits = better sound quality however you have to compromise for technical constraints because more bits = more required space.

member.summary: 8-bits per sample

member.name: F:TVA.Media.BitsPerSample.Bits16
member.summary: 16-bits per sample
member.remarks: This is the standard setting for CD audio quality

member.name: F:TVA.Media.BitsPerSample.Bits24
member.summary: 24-bits per sample

member.name: F:TVA.Media.BitsPerSample.Bits32
member.summary: 32-bits per sample

member.name: T:TVA.Media.WaveFormat
member.summary: Common WAVE audio encoding formats.

remarks.para: Microsoft defines more than 130 different audio encoding formats for WAVE files. Only the more common formats are defined here.

Note that PCM (i.e., Pulse Code Modulation) is a universal audio encoding format. It is a very common method of storing and transmitting uncompressed digital audio. Since it is a generic format, it can be read by most any audio application similar to the way a plain text file can be read by any word-processing program. PCM is used by Audio CDs and digital audio tapes (DATs). PCM is also a very common format for AIFF and WAV files.

member.name: M:TVA.Media.WaveFile.AddSample(System.Double)
member.summary: Add the sample to the wave file.
member.param: Sample to add to the wave file.

remarks.para: Sample is applied to all channels and cast to the appropriate size. Sample should be scaled by for integer based wave file formats to make sure sample will fit into defined by wave file.
If you have samples to apply to individual channels (e.g., for a stereo format), use the method instead.

member.name: M:TVA.Media.WaveFile.AddSamples(System.Double[])
member.summary: Adds a series of samples, one per channel, to the wave file.
member.param: Samples to add to the wave file.
member.remarks:
You need to pass in one sample for each defined channel (e.g., if wave is configured for stereo you will need to pass in two parameters).
Each sample will be cast to the appropriate size. Samples should be scaled by for integer based wave file formats to make sure samples will fit into defined by wave file.

member.name: M:TVA.Media.WaveFile.AddSampleBlock(TVA.LittleBinaryValue[])
member.summary: Adds a block of samples in native format to the wave file (e.g., if = 16, parameters need to be Int16 values). Note that parameter type is implicitly castable to common native types, including floating points.
member.param: Samples to add to the wave file.
member.remarks:
You need to pass in one sample for each defined channel (e.g., if wave is configured for stereo you will need to pass in two parameters).
You should only add values that match the wave file's (e.g., if wave file is configured for 16-bits only pass in Int16 values, casting if necessary).

member.name: M:TVA.Media.WaveFile.Combine(TVA.Media.WaveFile[])
member.summary: Combines wave files together, all starting at the same time, into a single file. This has the effect of playing two sound tracks simultaneously.
member.param: Wave files to combine
member.returns: Combined wave files.

remarks.para: This overload "equalizes" the volume of each source wave file. To specify a desired volume for each combined wave file use the overload that takes a series of volumes as a parameter.
Resulting sounds will overlap; no truncation is performed. Final wave file length will equal length of longest source file.
Combining sounds files with non-PCM based audio formats will have unexpected results.

member.name: M:TVA.Media.WaveFile.Combine(TVA.Media.WaveFile[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Combines wave files together, all starting at the same time, into a single file. This has the effect of playing two sound tracks simultaneously.
member.param: Wave files to combine
Volume for each wave file (0.0 to 1.0)
member.returns: Combined wave files.

remarks.para: Cumulatively, volumes cannot exceed 1.0 - these volumes represent a fractional percentage of volume to be applied to each wave file.
Resulting sounds will overlap; no truncation is performed. Final wave file length will equal length of longest source file.
Combining sounds files with non-PCM based audio formats will have unexpected results.

member.name: P:TVA.Media.WaveFile.ByteRate
member.summary: Gets or sets the byte rate used for buffer estimation.

remarks.para: This property is not usually changed. It will be automatically calculated for new wave files.
This is typically just the arithmetic result of: * * / 8. However, this value can be changed as needed to accomodate better buffer estimations during data read cycle.

member.name: P:TVA.Media.WaveFile.BlockAlignment
member.summary: Gets or sets the block size of a complete sample of data (i.e., samples for all channels of data at one instant in time).

remarks.para: This property is not usually changed. It will be automatically calculated for new wave files.
This is typically just the arithmetic result of: * / 8. However, this value can be changed as needed to accomodate even block-alignment of non-standard values.

member.name: P:TVA.Media.WaveFile.BitsPerSample

member.name: T:TVA.Int24
member.summary: Represents a 3-byte, 24-bit signed integer.

remarks.para: This class behaves like most other intrinsic signed integers but allows a 3-byte, 24-bit integer implementation that is often found in many digital-signal processing arenas and different kinds of protocol parsing. A signed 24-bit integer is typically used to save storage space on disk where its value range of -8388608 to 8388607 is sufficient, but the signed Int16 value range of -32768 to 32767 is too small.

This structure uses an Int32 internally for storage and most other common expected integer functionality, so using a 24-bit integer will not save memory. However, if the 24-bit signed integer range (-8388608 to 8388607) suits your data needs you can save disk space by only storing the three bytes that this integer actually consumes. You can do this by calling the Int24.GetBytes function to return a three byte binary array that can be serialized to the desired destination and then calling the Int24.GetValue function to restore the Int24 value from those three bytes.

All the standard operators for the Int24 have been fully defined for use with both Int24 and Int32 signed integers; you should find that without the exception Int24 can be compared and numerically calculated with an Int24 or Int32. Necessary casting should be minimal and typical use should be very simple - just as if you are using any other native signed integer.

member.summary: Converts the string representation of a number to its 24-bit signed integer equivalent. A return value indicates whether the conversion succeeded or failed.

When this method returns, contains the 24-bit signed integer value equivalent to the number contained in s, if the conversion succeeded, or zero if the conversion failed. The conversion fails if the s parameter is null, is not of the correct format, or represents a number less than Int24.MinValue or greater than Int24.MaxValue. This parameter is passed uninitialized.
member.returns: true if s was converted successfully; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:TVA.Int24.GetBytes(TVA.Int24)
member.summary: Returns the specified Int24 value as an array of three bytes.
member.param: Int24 value to convert to bytes.
member.returns: An array of bytes with length 3.

remarks.para: You can use this function in-lieu of a System.BitConverter.GetBytes(Int24) function.
Bytes will be returned in endian order of currently executing process architecture (little-endian on Intel platforms).

member.name: M:TVA.Int24.GetValue(System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a 24-bit signed integer from three bytes at a specified position in a byte array.
member.param: An array of bytes.
The starting position within value.
member.returns: A 24-bit signed integer formed by three bytes beginning at startIndex.

remarks.para: You can use this function in-lieu of a System.BitConverter.ToInt24 function.
Bytes endian order assumed to match that of currently executing process architecture (little-endian on Intel platforms).

member.exception: cannot be null.
is greater than length.
length from is too small to represent an .

member.name: T:TVA.DateTimeExtensions
member.summary: Defines extension functions related to Date/Time manipulation.

member.name: M:TVA.DateTimeExtensions.UtcTimeIsValid(System.DateTime,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Determines if the specified UTC time is valid, by comparing it to the system clock.
member.param: UTC time to test for validity.
The allowed lag time, in seconds, before assuming time is too old to be valid.
The allowed lead time, in seconds, before assuming time is too advanced to be valid.
member.returns: True, if time is within the specified range.

remarks.para: Time is considered valid if it exists within the specified lag time/lead time range of current time.
Note that lag time and lead time must be greater than zero, but can be set to sub-second intervals.

member.exception: LagTime and LeadTime must be greater than zero, but can be less than one.

member.name: M:TVA.DateTimeExtensions.LocalTimeIsValid(System.DateTime,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Determines if the specified local time is valid, by comparing it to the system clock.
member.param: Time to test for validity.
The allowed lag time, in seconds, before assuming time is too old to be valid.
The allowed lead time, in seconds, before assuming time is too advanced to be valid.
member.returns: True, if time is within the specified range.

remarks.para: Time is considered valid if it exists within the specified lag time/lead time range of current time.
Note that lag time and lead time must be greater than zero, but can be set to sub-second intervals.

member.exception: LagTime and LeadTime must be greater than zero, but can be less than one.

member.name: M:TVA.DateTimeExtensions.TimeIsValid(System.DateTime,System.DateTime,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Determines if time is valid, by comparing it to the specified current time.
member.param: Time to test for validity.
Specified current time (e.g., could be Date.Now or Date.UtcNow).
The allowed lag time, in seconds, before assuming time is too old to be valid.
The allowed lead time, in seconds, before assuming time is too advanced to be valid.
member.returns: True, if time is within the specified range.

remarks.para: Time is considered valid if it exists within the specified lag time/lead time range of current time.
Note that lag time and lead time must be greater than zero, but can be set to sub-second intervals.

member.exception: LagTime and LeadTime must be greater than zero, but can be less than one.

member.name: M:TVA.DateTimeExtensions.DistanceBeyondSecond(System.DateTime)
member.summary: Gets the distance, in , beyond the top of the second.
member.param: Timestamp to evaluate.
member.returns: Timestamp's tick distance from the top of the second.

member.name: M:TVA.DateTimeExtensions.BaselinedTimestamp(System.DateTime,TVA.BaselineTimeInterval)
member.summary: Creates a baselined timestamp which begins at the specified time interval.
member.param: Timestamp to baseline.
to which should be baselined.
member.returns: A new value that represents a baselined timestamp that begins at the specified .
member.remarks:
Baselining to the would return the value starting at zero milliseconds.
Baselining to the would return the value starting at zero seconds and milliseconds.
Baselining to the would return the value starting at zero minutes, seconds and milliseconds.
Baselining to the would return the value starting at zero hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds.
Baselining to the would return the value starting at day one, zero hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds.
Baselining to the would return the value starting at month one, day one, zero hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds.

member.name: M:TVA.CharExtensions.IsWordTerminator(System.Char)
member.summary: Tests a character to determine if it marks the end of a typical english word.
member.param: Input character to check.
member.returns: true if character is a work seperator.
member.remarks:
Preforms no testing for ASCII codes > 127.
Does not seperate words based on punctuation of ' % - _
However does include the angle bracket symbols < > as seperators
For reference the standard char tests are:
"IsSperator (1) == simple space (32 or 160) only.
IsPunctuation (23) == . , ! ? : ; " ' [ ] { } ( ) \ / @ % # * & - _ (plus other char's > 127)
IsSymbol (8) == $ + < > = ^ ` ~
IsWhiteSpace (6) == control char's 9 thry 13, plus 32 -- TAB, LF, VT, FF, CR, SP

member.name: M:TVA.CharExtensions.IsNumeric(System.Char)

member.param: The character to check.
member.returns: true if numeric character.

member.returns: Boolean value indicating a that the character is in the array.

member.name: T:TVA.UInt24
member.summary: Represents a 3-byte, 24-bit unsigned integer.

remarks.para: This class behaves like most other intrinsic unsigned integers but allows a 3-byte, 24-bit integer implementation that is often found in many digital-signal processing arenas and different kinds of protocol parsing. An unsigned 24-bit integer is typically used to save storage space on disk where its value range of 0 to 16777215 is sufficient, but the unsigned Int16 value range of 0 to 65535 is too small.

This structure uses an UInt32 internally for storage and most other common expected integer functionality, so using a 24-bit integer will not save memory. However, if the 24-bit unsigned integer range (0 to 16777215) suits your data needs you can save disk space by only storing the three bytes that this integer actually consumes. You can do this by calling the UInt24.GetBytes function to return a three byte binary array that can be serialized to the desired destination and then calling the UInt24.GetValue function to restore the UInt24 value from those three bytes.

All the standard operators for the UInt24 have been fully defined for use with both UInt24 and UInt32 unsigned integers; you should find that without the exception UInt24 can be compared and numerically calculated with an UInt24 or UInt32. Necessary casting should be minimal and typical use should be very simple - just as if you are using any other native unsigned integer.

member.name: F:TVA.UInt24.BitMask

is greater than length.

remarks.para: You can use this function in-lieu of a System.BitConverter.GetBytes function.
Bytes will be returned in endian order of currently executing process architecture (little-endian on Intel platforms).

member.name: M:TVA.UInt24.TryParse(System.String,TVA.UInt24@)
member.summary: Converts the string representation of a number to its 24-bit unsigned integer equivalent. A return value indicates whether the conversion succeeded or failed.
member.param: A string containing a number to convert.

When this method returns, contains the 24-bit unsigned integer value equivalent to the number contained in s, if the conversion succeeded, or zero if the conversion failed. The conversion fails if the s parameter is null, is not of the correct format, or represents a number less than UInt24.MinValue or greater than UInt24.MaxValue. This parameter is passed uninitialized.
member.returns: true if s was converted successfully; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:TVA.UInt24.TryParse(System.String,System.Globalization.NumberStyles,System.IFormatProvider,TVA.UInt24@)

When this method returns, contains the 24-bit unsigned integer value equivalent to the number contained in s, if the conversion succeeded, or zero if the conversion failed. The conversion fails if the s parameter is null, is not in a format compliant with style, or represents a number less than UInt24.MinValue or greater than UInt24.MaxValue. This parameter is passed uninitialized.

member.returns: true if s was converted successfully; otherwise, false.

member.name: T:TVA.IO.IsamDataFileBase`1
member.summary: An abstract class that defines the read/write capabilities for ISAM (Indexed Sequential Access Method) file.
member.typeparam: of the records the file contains. This must implement the interface.

remarks.para: This ISAM implementation keeps all the records in memory, so it may not be suitable for very large files. Since data is stored in memory using a list, the maximum number of possible supported records will be 2,147,483,647 (i.e., Int32.MaxValue).
See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISAM for more information on ISAM files.

member.name: M:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.Stop
member.summary: Stops item processing.

member.name: M:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.Flush
member.summary: Blocks the current thread, if the is active (i.e., user has called "Start" method), until all items in are processed, and then stops the .

remarks.para: Begins processing items as quickly as possible, regardless of currently defined process interval, until all items in the have been processed. Stops the when this function ends. This method is typically called on shutdown to make sure any remaining queued items get processed before the is destructed.

It is possible for items to be added to the while the flush is executing. The flush will continue to process items as quickly as possible until the is empty. Unless the user stops queueing items to be processed, the flush call may never return (not a happy situtation on shutdown). For this reason, during this function call, requeueing of items on exception or process timeout is temporarily disabled.
The does not clear queue prior to destruction. If the user fails to call this method before the class is destructed, there may be items that remain unprocessed in the .

member.name: M:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.DataAdded
member.summary: Notifies a class that data was added, so it can begin processing data.

remarks.para: Derived classes *must* make sure to call this method after data gets added, so that the process timer can be enabled for intervaled and data processing can begin.
To make sure items in the always get processed, this function is expected to be invoked from within a SyncLock of the exposed SyncRoot (i.e., m_processQueue).

member.name: E:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ItemProcessed
member.summary: Event that is raised after an item has been successfully processed.

remarks.para: Allows custom handling of successfully processed items.
Allows notification when an item has completed processing in the allowed amount of time, if a process timeout is specified.
Raised only when ProcessingStyle = OneAtATime (i.e., is defined).

member.name: E:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ItemsProcessed
member.summary: Event that is raised after an array of items have been successfully processed.

remarks.para: Allows custom handling of successfully processed items.
Allows notification when an item has completed processing in the allowed amount of time, if a process timeout is specified.
Raised only when when ProcessingStyle = ManyAtOnce (i.e., is defined).

member.name: E:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ItemTimedOut
member.summary: Event that is raised if an item's processing time exceeds the specified process timeout.

remarks.para: Allows custom handling of items that took too long to process.
Raised only when ProcessingStyle = OneAtATime (i.e., is defined).

member.name: E:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ItemsTimedOut
member.summary: Event that is raised if the processing time for an array of items exceeds the specified process timeout.

remarks.para: Allows custom handling of items that took too long to process.
Raised only when ProcessingStyle = ManyAtOnce (i.e., is defined).

member.name: E:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ProcessException
member.summary: Event that is raised if an exception is encountered while attempting to processing an item in the .
member.remarks: Processing will not stop for any exceptions thrown by the user function, but any captured exceptions will be exposed through this event.

member.name: P:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ProcessItemFunction
member.summary: Gets or sets the user function for processing individual items in the one at a time.

remarks.para: Cannot be defined simultaneously with .
A must be defined to process a single item at a time or many items at once.
Implementation makes ProcessingStyle = OneAtATime.

member.name: P:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ProcessItemsFunction
member.summary: Gets or sets the user function for processing multiple items in the at once.

remarks.para: This function and cannot be defined at the same time
A must be defined to process a single item at a time or many items at once
Implementation of this function makes ProcessingStyle = ManyAtOnce

member.name: P:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.CanProcessItemFunction
member.summary: Gets or sets the user function determining if an item is ready to be processed.

member.name: P:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ProcessingIsRealTime
member.summary: Gets indicator that items will be processed in real-time.

member.name: P:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ThreadingMode
member.summary: Gets the current for the (i.e., synchronous or asynchronous).

remarks.para: The maximum number of processing threads determines the .
If the maximum threads are set to one, item processing will be synchronous (i.e., ThreadingMode = Synchronous).
If the maximum threads are more than one, item processing will be asynchronous (i.e., ThreadingMode = Asynchronous).

Note that for asynchronous , the processing interval will control how many threads are spawned at once. If items are processed faster than the specified processing interval, only one process thread will ever be spawned at a time. To ensure multiple threads are utilized to items, lower the process interval (minimum process interval is 1 millisecond).

member.name: P:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ProcessingStyle
member.summary: Gets the item for the (i.e., one at a time or many at once).

remarks.para: The implemented item processing function determines the .

If the is ManyAtOnce, all available items in the are presented for processing at each processing interval. If you expect items to be processed in the order in which they were received, make sure you use a synchronous . Real-time are inherently synchronous.

member.name: P:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ProcessInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets the interval, in milliseconds, on which new items begin processing.

member.name: P:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.MaximumThreads
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of threads to process simultaneously.
member.value: Sets the maximum number of processing threads.
member.returns: Maximum number of processing threads.
member.remarks: If MaximumThreads is set to one, item processing will be synchronous (i.e., ThreadingMode = Synchronous)

member.name: P:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ProcessTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum time, in milliseconds, allowed for processing an item.
member.value: Sets the maximum number of milliseconds allowed to process an item.
member.returns: The maximum number of milliseconds allowed to process an item.
member.remarks: Set to Timeout.Infinite (i.e., -1) to allow processing to take as long as needed.

member.name: P:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.RequeueOnTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not to automatically place an item back into the if the processing times out.
member.remarks: Ignored if the ProcessTimeout is set to Timeout.Infinite (i.e., -1).

member.name: P:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.RequeueModeOnTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the mode of insertion used (prefix or suffix) when at item is placed back into the after processing times out.
member.remarks: Only relevant when RequeueOnTimeout = True.

member.name: P:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.RequeueOnException
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not to automatically place an item back into the if an exception occurs while processing.

member.name: P:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.RequeueModeOnException
member.summary: Gets or sets the mode of insertion used (prefix or suffix) when at item is placed back into the after an exception occurs while processing.
member.remarks: Only relevant when RequeueOnException = True.

member.name: P:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.SyncRoot
member.summary: Returns reference to internal IList that should be used to synchronize access to the .
member.returns: Reference to internal IList that should be used to synchronize access to the .

remarks.para: Note that all the methods of this class are already individually synchronized; however, to safely enumerate through each element (i.e., to make sure elements do not change during enumeration), derived classes and end users should perform their own synchronization by implementing a SyncLock using this SyncRoot property.
We return a typed object for synchronization as an optimization. Returning a generic object requires that SyncLock implementations validate that the referenced object is not a value type at run time.

member.name: P:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.IsSynchronized
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether access to the is synchronized (thread safe). Always returns true for .
member.returns: true, is always synchronized (thread safe).
member.remarks: The is effectively "synchronized" since all functions SyncLock operations internally.

member.summary: Allows derived classes to access the interfaced internal directly.

member.name: T:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ProcessItemFunctionSignature
member.summary: Function signature that defines a method to process items one at a time.
member.param: Item to be processed.

remarks.para: Required unless is implemented.
Creates an asynchronous to process individual items - one item at a time - on multiple threads.

member.name: T:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ProcessItemsFunctionSignature
member.summary: Function signature that defines a method to process multiple items at once.
member.param: Items to be processed.

remarks.para: Required unless is implemented.
Creates an asynchronous to process groups of items simultaneously on multiple threads.

member.name: T:TVA.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.CanProcessItemFunctionSignature
member.summary: Function signature that determines if an item can be currently processed.
member.param: Item to be checked for processing availablity.
member.returns: True, if item can be processed. The default is true.

remarks.para: Implementation of this function is optional. It is assumed that an item can be processed if this function is not defined
Items must eventually get to a state where they can be processed, or they will remain in the indefinitely.

Note that when this function is implemented and ProcessingStyle = ManyAtOnce (i.e., is defined), then each item presented for processing must evaluate as "CanProcessItem = True" before any items are processed.

member.name: T:TVA.Media.RiffHeaderChunk
member.summary: Represents the header chunk in a RIFF media format file.

member.name: T:TVA.Media.RiffChunk
member.summary: Represents the type ID and size for a "chunk" in a RIFF media format file.

remarks.para: The Resource Interchange File Format (RIFF) is a generic meta-format for storing data in tagged chunks. It was introduced in 1991 by Microsoft and IBM, and was presented by Microsoft as the default format for Windows 3.1 multimedia files. It is based on Electronic Arts's Interchange File Format, introduced in 1985, the only difference being that multi-byte integers are in little-endian format, native to the 80x86 processor series used in IBM PCs, rather than the big-endian format native to the 68k processor series used in Amiga and Apple Macintosh computers, where IFF files were heavily used. (The specification for AIFF, the big-endian analogue of RIFF, was published by Apple Computer in 1988.) The Microsoft implementation is mostly known through file formats like AVI, ANI and WAV, which use the RIFF meta-format as their basis.

Some common RIFF file types:
File extension Description
WAV Windows audio file
AVI Windows audio/video file
ANI Animated Windows cursors
RMI Windows RIFF MIDI file
CDR CorelDRAW vector graphics file

member.name: T:TVA.ErrorManagement.SmtpTraceListener
member.summary: Represents an e-mail based .
member.example:
Below is the config file entry required for enabling e-mail based tracing using :
<configuration> <system.diagnostics> <trace> <listeners> <add name="SmtpTraceListener" type="TVA.ErrorManagement.SmtpTraceListener,TVA.Core" initializeData="sender@email.com,recipient@email.com,smtp.email.com"/> </listeners> </trace> </system.diagnostics> </configuration>

member.name: T:TVA.Collections.DictionaryList`2
member.summary: Represents a sorted dictionary style list that supports .

remarks.para: Have you ever needed the quick look-up feature on a Dictionary (e.g., Hashtable), but ended up missing the indexed or sequential access like you have in a list? You may have wondered why the .NET dictionary class doesnt implement the IList interface which allows this. The reason IDictionary implementations do not normally implement the IList interface is because of ambiguity that is caused when implementing an integer key. For example, if you created a dictionary style class with a key of type "Integer" that actually did implement IList(Of T), you would not be able to access items in the IList interface by index without "casting" the class as IList. This is because the Item property in both the IDictionary and IList would have the same parameters. Note, however, that generics in .NET 2.0 gladly allow a class to implement both IDictionary and IList (even specifying as Integer as the key) so long you as you are happy knowing that the compiler will choose if you access your items by index or key. Given that caveat, there are many times when you need a dictionary style collection but also desire an IList implementation so the class can be used in other ways without conversion. As a result of these needs, weve added a generic class to code library called a DictionaryList -- which is essentially just a sorted dictionary style list (i.e., SortedList) that implements the IList(Of T) interface (specifically as IList(Of KeyValuePair(Of TKey, TValue))). You will find all of your convenient expected methods related to both dictionaries and lists; that is, you can look-up items by key or by index. The class works perfectly for any non-Integer based key (e.g., String, custom class, etc.) -- note that specifying an Integer as the key for the class wont cause an error, but it also will not be very useful. However, you can specify the key for your DictionaryList as a "Long," which allows you to use long integers for keyed look-ups and regular integers for indexed access--the best of both worlds! In summary, I would not change your programming habits to start using this for "my collection for everything," as nothing comes for free; however, if you have a need for a "hybrid" collection class, this fits the bill.

Important note about using an "Integer" as the key for this class: IDictionary implementations do not normally implement the IList interface because of ambiguity that is caused when implementing an integer key. For example, if you implement this class with a key of type "Integer" you will not be able to access items in the queue by index without "casting" the class as IList. This is because the Item property in both the IDictionary and IList would have the same parameters.

Note that prior to the addition of Generics in .NET, the class that performed a similar function was the "NameObjectCollectionBase" in the System.Collections.Specialized namespace which specifically allowed item access by either key or by index. This class is similar in function but instead is a generic class allowing use with any strongly typed key or value.

member.typeparam: Generic key type.
Genervic value type.

member.param: Fundamental frequency of the desired note in Hz.
Sample index (represents time anywhere from zero to full length of song).
If useful, total period for note in whole samples per second (i.e., seconds of time * ) over which to compute timbre.
Number of samples per second.
member.returns: The amplitude for a simulated clarinet note at the given time.
member.remarks: This method computes an amplitude representing the acoustic pressure of a second-order harmonic series approaching a square wave (i.e., Sin(f) + Sin(3f)/3) of the given frequency for the given time to simulate an organ sound.

member.name: M:TVA.Media.Music.Timbre.OddHarmonicSeries(System.Double,System.Int64,System.Int64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates an odd harmonic series for the given frequency and time.
member.param: Fundamental frequency of the desired note in Hz.
Sample index (represents time anywhere from zero to full length of song).
If useful, total period for note in whole samples per second (i.e., seconds of time * ) over which to compute timbre.
Number of samples per second.
member.returns: The amplitude for a simulated clarinet note at the given time.
member.remarks: This method computes an amplitude representing the acoustic pressure of an odd harmonic series of the given frequency for the given time. Algorithm: Sin(f) + Sin(3f)/3 + Sin(5f)/5, etc.

member.name: M:TVA.Media.Music.Timbre.EvenHarmonicSeries(System.Double,System.Int64,System.Int64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates an even harmonic series for the given frequency and time.
member.param: Fundamental frequency of the desired note in Hz.
Sample index (represents time anywhere from zero to full length of song).
If useful, total period for note in whole samples per second (i.e., seconds of time * ) over which to compute timbre.
Number of samples per second.
member.returns: The amplitude for a simulated clarinet note at the given time.
member.remarks: This method computes an amplitude representing the acoustic pressure of an even harmonic series of the given frequency for the given time. Algorithm: Sin(2f) + Sin(4f)/3 + Sin(6f)/5, etc.

member.name: T:TVA.IO.Checksums.ChecksumType
member.summary: Indicates type of CRC-16 calculation performed.

member.name: F:TVA.IO.Checksums.ChecksumType.Crc16
member.summary: Regular CRC-16 calculation.

member.name: F:TVA.IO.Checksums.ChecksumType.ModBus
member.summary: ModBus CRC-16 calculation.

member.name: T:TVA.IO.Checksums.Crc16
member.summary: Generates a byte-wise 16-bit CRC calculation.

remarks.para: 2-byte (16-bit) CRC: The generating polynomial is
G(X) = X + X + X + X

member.name: M:TVA.IO.Checksums.Crc16.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the Crc16 class. The checksum starts off with a value of 0x0000.

member.name: M:TVA.IO.Checksums.Crc16.#ctor(TVA.IO.Checksums.ChecksumType)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the Crc16 class.
member.param: Type of calculation to perform, CRC-16 or ModBus.

member.name: M:TVA.IO.Checksums.Crc16.Reset
member.summary: Resets the CRC-16 data checksum as if no update was ever called.

member.name: M:TVA.IO.Checksums.Crc16.Reset(TVA.IO.Checksums.ChecksumType)
member.summary: Resets the CRC-16 data checksum as if no update was ever called.
member.param: Type of CRC calculation. CRC-16 resets to 0x0000, ModBus resets to 0xFFFF

member.name: M:TVA.IO.Checksums.Crc16.Update(System.Byte)
member.summary: Updates the checksum with the byte value.
member.param: The value to use for the update.

member.name: M:TVA.IO.Checksums.Crc16.Update(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Updates the checksum with the bytes taken from the array.
member.param: buffer an array of bytes

member.name: M:TVA.IO.Checksums.Crc16.Update(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds the byte array to the data checksum.
member.param: The buffer which contains the data
The offset in the buffer where the data starts
The number of data bytes to update the CRC with.

member.name: P:TVA.IO.Checksums.Crc16.Value
member.summary: Returns the CRC-16 data checksum computed so far.

member.name: M:TVA.BitExtensions.BitRotL(System.Byte,System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs rightwise bit-rotation for the specified number of rotations.
member.param: Value used for bit-rotation.
Number of rotations to perform.
member.returns: Value that has its bits rotated to the right the specified number of times.
member.remarks: Actual rotation direction is from a big-endian perspective - this is an artifact of the native .NET bit shift operators. As a result bits may actually appear to rotate right on little-endian architectures.

member.name: M:TVA.BitExtensions.BitRotL(System.SByte,System.Int32)

member.remarks: Note that some .NET languages (e.g., Visual Basic) will not initialize member elements before call to constuctor, in this case should be set to false, then the method should be called manually after all properties have been initialized. member.name: T:TVA.Ticks
member.summary: Represents an instant in time, or time period, as a 64-bit signed integer with a value that is expressed as the number of 100-nanosecond intervals that have elapsed since 12:00:00 midnight, January 1, 0001.

remarks.para: can represent an "instant in time" and therefore can be used exactly like a . The difference between and is that is essentially a long integer (i.e., an ) which represents the number of ticks that have elapsed since 12:00:00 midnight, January 1, 0001 with each tick having a resolution of 100-nanoseconds. You would use in places where you needed to directly represent time in high-resolution, i.e., time with subsecond accuracy, using an object that will act like a long integer but handle time conversions. can also represent a "time period" (e.g., the number of ticks elapsed since a process started) and thus can also be used like a ; when used in this manner the method can be used to convert the value into a handy textual representation of elapsed years, days, hours, minutes and seconds.

This class behaves just like an representing a time in ticks; it is implictly castable to and from an and therefore can be generally used "as" an Int64 directly. It is also implicitly castable to and from a , a , an and a .

member.summary: Number of 100-nanosecond ticks in one microsecond.

member.name: F:TVA.Ticks.PerMinute
member.summary: Number of 100-nanosecond ticks in one minute.

member.name: F:TVA.Ticks.PerHour
member.summary: Number of 100-nanosecond ticks in one hour.

member.name: F:TVA.Ticks.PerDay

member.name: M:TVA.Ticks.UtcTimeIsValid(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Determines if time, represented by value in UTC time, is valid by comparing it to the system clock.
member.param: The allowed lag time, in seconds, before assuming time is too old to be valid.
The allowed lead time, in seconds, before assuming time is too advanced to be valid.
member.returns: True, if UTC time represented by value, is within the specified range.
member.remarks: Time, represented by value, is considered valid if it exists within the specified and range of system clock time in UTC. Note that and must be greater than zero, but can be set to sub-second intervals.
member.exception: and must be greater than zero, but can be less than one.

The allowed lag time, in ticks, before assuming time is too old to be valid.
The allowed lead time, in ticks, before assuming time is too advanced to be valid.
member.returns: True, if time represented by value, is within the specified range.
member.remarks: Time, represented by value, is considered valid if it exists within the specified and range of . Note that and must be greater than zero.
member.exception: and must be greater than zero.

member.name: M:TVA.Ticks.DistanceBeyondSecond
member.summary: Gets the distance, in 100-nanoseconds intervals, beyond the top of the second in the timestamp represented by the .
member.returns: Number of 100-nanoseconds intervals value is from the top of the second.

member.name: M:TVA.Ticks.BaselinedTimestamp(TVA.BaselineTimeInterval)
member.summary: Creates a new value that represents a baselined timestamp, in 100-nanoseconds intervals, that begins at the beginning of the specified time interval.
member.param: to which timestamp should be baselined.
member.returns: A new value that represents a baselined timestamp, in 100-nanoseconds intervals, that begins at the specified .
member.remarks:
Baselining to the would return the value starting at zero milliseconds.
Baselining to the would return the value starting at zero seconds and milliseconds.
Baselining to the would return the value starting at zero minutes, seconds and milliseconds.
Baselining to the would return the value starting at zero hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds.
Baselining to the would return the value starting at day one, zero hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds.
Baselining to the would return the value starting at month one, day one, zero hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds.

member.name: M:TVA.Ticks.ToElapsedTimeString
member.summary: Converts the value into a textual representation of years, days, hours, minutes and seconds.
member.remarks: Note that this ToString overload will not display fractional seconds. To allow display of fractional seconds, or completely remove second resolution from the textual representation, use the overload instead.
member.returns: The string representation of the value of this instance, consisting of the number of years, days, hours, minutes and seconds represented by this value.

member.name: M:TVA.Ticks.ToElapsedTimeString(System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts the value into a textual representation of years, days, hours, minutes and seconds with the specified number of fractional digits.
member.param: Number of fractional digits to display for seconds.
member.remarks: Set to -1 to suppress seconds display.
member.returns: The string representation of the value of this instance, consisting of the number of years, days, hours, minutes and seconds represented by this value.

member.name: M:TVA.Ticks.ToElapsedTimeString(System.Int32,System.String[])
member.summary: Converts the value into a textual representation of years, days, hours, minutes and seconds with the specified number of fractional digits given string array of time names.
member.param: Number of fractional digits to display for seconds.
Time names array to use during textual conversion.

remarks.para: Set to -1 to suppress seconds display.

array needs one string entry for each of the following names:
"Year", "Years", "Day", "Days", "Hour", "Hours", "Minute", "Minutes", "Second", "Seconds", "Less Than 60 Seconds", "0 Seconds".

member.returns: The string representation of the value of this instance, consisting of the number of years, days, hours, minutes and seconds represented by this value.

member.name: T:TVA.Threading.ManagedThreadPool
member.summary: Defines a managed thread pool
member.remarks: This class works like the normal thread pool but provides the benefit of automatic tracking of queued threads through the ManagedThreads collection, returns a reference to the queued thread with the ability to dequeue and/or abort, total thread runtime and the ability to run the queued thread in an alternate execution context

member.name: M:TVA.Threading.ManagedThreadPool.QueueUserWorkItem(System.Threading.ThreadStart)
member.summary: Queues a work item for processing on the managed thread pool
member.param: A WaitCallback representing the method to execute.
member.returns: Reference to queued thread
member.remarks: This differs from the normal thread pool QueueUserWorkItem function in that it does not return a success value determing if item was queued, but rather a reference to to the managed thread that was actually placed on the queue.

member.name: M:TVA.Threading.ManagedThreadPool.QueueUserWorkItem(System.Threading.ParameterizedThreadStart)

An object containing data to be used by the method.
member.returns: Reference to queued thread
member.remarks: This differs from the normal thread pool QueueUserWorkItem function in that it does not return a success value determing if item was queued, but rather a reference to to the managed thread that was actually placed on the queue.

member.name: T:TVA.Media.Music.DampingFunction
member.summary: Provides a function signature for methods that damp an amplitude representing a lowering of the acoustic pressure over time.
member.param: Sample index (0 to - 1).
Total period, in whole samples per second (i.e., seconds of time * ), over which to perform damping.
Number of samples per second, if useful for calculation.
member.returns: Scaling factor in the range of zero to one used to damp an amplitude at the given sample index.

member.name: T:TVA.Media.Music.Damping
member.summary: Defines a few damping functions.

member.name: M:TVA.Media.Music.Damping.Natural(System.Int64,System.Int64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Produces a natural damping curve very similar to that of a string based instrument - strong at first and damping quickly over time from 1 to 0 over the .
member.param: Sample index (0 to - 1).
Total period, in whole samples per second (i.e., seconds of time * ), over which to perform damping.
Number of samples per second, if useful for calculation.
member.returns: Scaling factor used to damp an amplitude at the given time.
member.remarks: This damping algorithm combines both the logarithmic and linear damping algoriths to produce a very natural damping curve.

member.name: M:TVA.Media.Music.Damping.Logarithmic(System.Int64,System.Int64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Produces a logarithmic damping curve - strong at first and damping quickly over time from 1 to 0 over the .
member.param: Sample index (0 to - 1).
Total period, in whole samples per second (i.e., seconds of time * ), over which to perform damping.
Number of samples per second, if useful for calculation.
member.returns: Scaling factor used to damp an amplitude at the given time.
member.remarks: This damping would be similar to that of a note produced by a string based instrument.

member.name: M:TVA.Media.Music.Damping.InverseLogarithmic(System.Int64,System.Int64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Produces an inverse logarithmic damping curve - slowly damping with a sharp end from 1 to 0 over the .
member.param: Sample index (0 to - 1).
Total period, in whole samples per second (i.e., seconds of time * ), over which to perform damping.
Number of samples per second, if useful for calculation.
member.returns: Scaling factor used to damp an amplitude at the given time.
member.remarks: This damping would be similar to that of a note produced on an electronic keyboard or a breath based instrument.

member.name: M:TVA.Media.Music.Damping.Linear(System.Int64,System.Int64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Produces a linear damping curve - damping with a perfect slope from 1 to 0 over the .
member.param: Sample index (0 to - 1).
Total period, in whole samples per second (i.e., seconds of time * ), over which to perform damping.
Number of samples per second, if useful for calculation.
member.returns: Scaling factor used to damp an amplitude at the given time.

member.name: M:TVA.Media.Music.Damping.ReverseLinear(System.Int64,System.Int64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Produces a reverse linear damping curve - damping with a perfect slope from 0 to 1 over the .
member.param: Sample index (0 to - 1).
Total period, in whole samples per second (i.e., seconds of time * ), over which to perform damping.
Number of samples per second, if useful for calculation.
member.returns: Scaling factor used to damp an amplitude at the given time.
member.remarks: This is just used for an interesting note effect.

member.name: M:TVA.Media.Music.Damping.Sinusoidal(System.Int64,System.Int64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Produces a sinusoidal damping curve oscillating from 1 to 0 to 1 over the .
member.param: Sample index (0 to - 1).
Total period, in whole samples per second (i.e., seconds of time * ), over which to perform damping.
Number of samples per second, if useful for calculation.
member.returns: Scaling factor used to damp an amplitude at the given time.
member.remarks: This is just used for an interesting note effect.

member.name: M:TVA.Media.Music.Damping.Zero(System.Int64,System.Int64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Produces a damping signature that represents no damping over time.
member.param: Sample index (0 to - 1).
Total period, in whole samples per second (i.e., seconds of time * ), over which to perform damping.
Number of samples per second, if useful for calculation.
member.returns: Returns a scalar of 1.0 regardless to time.
member.remarks: Zero damped sounds would be produced by synthetic sources such as an electronic keyboard.

member.name: T:TVA.ErrorManagement.ErrorModule
member.summary: Represents an HTTP module that can be used to handle exceptions globally in Web Sites and Web Services.
member.example:
Below is the config file entry required for enabling error handling using :
<configuration> <system.web> <httpModules> <add name="ErrorModule" type="TVA.ErrorManagement.ErrorModule, TVA.Core" /> </httpModules> </system.web> </configuration>
Below is the config file entry required for changing the settings of :
<configuration> <configSections> <section name="categorizedSettings" type="TVA.Configuration.CategorizedSettingsSection, TVA.Core" /> </configSections> <categorizedSettings> <errorLogger> <add name="LogToUI" value="False" description="True if an encountered exception is to be logged to the User Interface; otherwise False." encrypted="false" /> <add name="LogToFile" value="True" description="True if an encountered exception is to be logged to a file; otherwise False." encrypted="false" /> <add name="LogToEmail" value="False" description="True if an email is to be sent to ContactEmail with the details of an encountered exception; otherwise False." encrypted="false" /> <add name="LogToEventLog" value="True" description="True if an encountered exception is to be logged to the Event Log; otherwise False." encrypted="false" /> <add name="LogToScreenshot" value="False" description="True if a screenshot is to be taken when an exception is encountered; otherwise False." encrypted="false" /> <add name="SmtpServer" value="smtp.email.com" description="Name of the SMTP server to be used for sending the email messages." encrypted="false" /> <add name="ContactEmail" value="" description="Comma-seperated list of recipient email addresses for the email message." encrypted="false" /> <add name="ContactName" value="" description="Name of the person that the end-user can contact when an exception is encountered." encrypted="false" /> <add name="ContactPhone" value="" description="Phone number of the person that the end-user can contact when an exception is encountered." encrypted="false" /> <add name="HandleUnhandledException" value="True" description="True if unhandled exceptions are to be handled automatically; otherwise False." encrypted="false" /> <add name="ExitOnUnhandledException" value="False" description="True if the application must exit when an unhandled exception is encountered; otherwise False." encrypted="false" /> </errorLogger> </categorizedSettings> </configuration>

member.name: M:TVA.ErrorManagement.ErrorModule.Init(System.Web.HttpApplication)
member.summary: Initializes the and prepares it to handle requests.
member.param: The to use for initialization.

member.name: T:TVA.ErrorManagement.ErrorLogger
member.summary: Represents a logger that can be used for logging handled as well as unhandled exceptions across multiple application types (Windows Application, Console Application, Windows Service, Web Application, Web Service).
member.remarks: Adapted from exception handling code by Jeff Atwood of CodingHorror.com. Demo projects for handling unhandled exception in both windows and web environment by Jeff Atwood are available at The Code Project web site. See: http://www.codeproject.com/script/articles/list_articles.asp?userid=450027
