member.name: M:TVA.Common.IIf``1(System.Boolean,``0,``0)
member.summary: Returns one of two strongly-typed objects.
member.returns: One of two objects, depending on the evaluation of given expression.
member.param: The expression you want to evaluate.
Returned if expression evaluates to True.
Returned if expression evaluates to False.
member.typeparam: Return type used for immediate expression

remarks.para: This function acts as a strongly-typed immediate if (a.k.a. inline if).
It is expected that this function will only be used in Visual Basic.NET as a strongly-typed IIf replacement.

member.name: M:TVA.Common.CreateArray``1(System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a strongly-typed Array.
member.returns: New array of specified type.
member.param: Desired length of new array.
member.typeparam: Return type for new array.

remarks.para: It is expected that this function will only be used in Visual Basic.NET.

The Array.CreateInstance provides better performance and more direct CLR access for array creation (not to mention less confusion on the matter of array lengths) in VB.NET, however the returned System.Array is not typed properly. This function properly casts the return array based on the the type specification helping when Option Strict is enabled.

example.code: Dim buffer As Byte() = CreateArray(Of Byte)(12) Dim matrix As Integer()() = CreateArray(Of Integer())(10)

member.name: M:TVA.Common.CreateArray``1(System.Int32,``0)
member.summary: Creates a strongly-typed Array with an initial value parameter.
member.returns: New array of specified type.
member.param: Desired length of new array.
Value used to initialize all array elements.
member.typeparam: Return type for new array.
member.remarks: It is expected that this function will only be used in Visual Basic.NET.

example.code: Dim elements As Integer() = CreateArray(12, -1) Dim names As String() = CreateArray(100, "undefined")

member.name: T:TVA.Scheduling.Schedule
member.summary: Represents a schedule defined using UNIX crontab syntax.

remarks.para: Operators:

There are several ways of specifying multiple date/time values in a field:
The comma (',') operator specifies a list of values, for example: "1,3,4,7,8"
The dash ('-') operator specifies a range of values, for example: "1-6", which is equivalent to "1,2,3,4,5,6"
The asterisk ('*') operator specifies all possible values for a field. For example, an asterisk in the hour time field would be equivalent to 'every hour' (subject to matching other specified fields).
The slash ('/') operator (called "step"), which can be used to skip a given number of values. For example, "*/3" in the hour time field is equivalent to "0,3,6,9,12,15,18,21". So "*" specifies 'every hour' but the "*/3" means only those hours divisible by 3.
Fields:
Each of the patterns from the first five fields may be either * (an asterisk), which matches all legal values, or a list of elements separated by commas.
See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cron for more information.

member.name: P:TVA.Media.WaveFormatChunk.ByteRate
member.summary: Gets or sets the byte rate used for buffer estimation.

remarks.para: This property is not usually changed. It will be automatically calculated for new wave files.
This is typically just the arithmetic result of: * * / 8. However, this value can be changed as needed to accomodate better buffer estimations during data read cycle.

member.name: P:TVA.Media.WaveFormatChunk.BlockAlignment
member.summary: Gets or sets the block size of a complete sample of data (i.e., samples for all channels of data at one instant in time).

remarks.para: This property is not usually changed. It will be automatically calculated for new wave files.
This is typically just the arithmetic result of: * / 8. However, this value can be changed as needed to accomodate even block-alignment of non-standard values.

member.name: M:TVA.Threading.ManagedThread.Join
member.summary: Blocks the calling thread until a thread terminates or the specified time elapses, while continuing to perform standard COM and SendMessage pumping.
member.remarks: This is only available for standard threads - queued threads don't have an associated thread until they are executing.

member.name: M:TVA.Threading.ManagedThread.Join(System.Int32)
member.summary: Blocks the calling thread until a thread terminates or the specified time elapses, while continuing to perform standard COM and SendMessage pumping.
member.param: The number of milliseconds to wait for the thread to terminate.
member.returns: true if the thread has terminated; false if the thread has not terminated after the amount of time specified by the millisecondsTimeout parameter has elapsed.
member.remarks: This is only available for standard threads - queued threads don't have an associated thread until they are executing.

member.name: M:TVA.Threading.ManagedThread.Join(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Blocks the calling thread until a thread terminates or the specified time elapses, while continuing to perform standard COM and SendMessage pumping.
member.param: A TimeSpan set to the amount of time to wait for the thread to terminate.
member.returns: true if the thread terminated; false if the thread has not terminated after the amount of time specified by the timeout parameter has elapsed.
member.remarks: This is only available for standard threads - queued threads don't have an associated thread until they are executing.

member.name: P:TVA.Threading.ManagedThread.Priority
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating the scheduling priority of a thread.
member.returns: One of the ThreadPriority values. The default value is Normal.
member.remarks: Changing of this value is only available to standard threads - you can't change the priorty of queued threads since they are already allocated and owned by the .NET thread pool.

member.name: M:TVA.StringExtensions.ParseKeyValuePairs(System.String)
member.summary: Parses key value pair parameters from a string. Parameter pairs are delimited by an equals sign, and multiple pairs separated by a semi-colon.
member.param: Key pair string to parse.
member.returns: Dictionary of key/value pairs.

remarks.para: Parses a string formatted like a typical connection string, e.g.: IP=localhost; Port=1002; MaxEvents=50; UseTimeout=True. Note that "keys" are case-insensitive.
Values can be escaped within braces to contain nested key value pair expressions like the following: normalKVP=-1; nestedKVP={p1=true; p2=0.001}. Only one level of nesting is supported.

member.exception: value is null.
Only one level of tagged value expressions are allowed -or- encountered end value delimeter '}' before start value delimeter '{'.

Character that delimits key from value (e.g., would be an "=" in a typical connection string).
member.returns: Dictionary of key/value pairs.

remarks.para: Parses a key value string that contains one or many pairs. Note that "keys" are case-insensitive.
Values can be escaped within braces to contain nested key value pair expressions like the following: normalKVP=-1; nestedKVP={p1=true; p2=0.001}. Only one level of nesting is supported.

member.exception: value is null.
All delimeters must be unique.
Only one level of tagged value expressions are allowed -or- encountered end value delimeter '}' before start value delimeter '{'.

member.name: M:TVA.Media.Music.Note.CalculateValueTime(TVA.Media.Music.Tempo)
member.summary: Calculates the actual time duration, in seconds, for the specified tempo that the note value will last. For example, if tempo is M.M. 120 quarter-notes per minte, then each quarter-note would last a half-second.
member.param: Tempo used to calculate note value time.
member.returns: Calculated note value time.
member.remarks: Calculated value is cached and available from property.

member.name: T:TVA.EndianOrder
member.summary: Represents an endian byte order interoperability class.
member.remarks: Intel systems use little-endian byte order, other systems, such as Unix, use big-endian byte ordering. Little-endian ordering means bits are ordered such that the bit whose in-memory representation is right-most is the most-significant-bit in a byte. Big-endian ordering means bits are ordered such that the bit whose in-memory representation is left-most is the most-significant-bit in a byte.

member.name: T:TVA.Collections.KeyedProcessQueue`2
member.summary: Represents a keyed collection of items that get processed on independent threads with a consumer provided function.
member.typeparam: Type of keys used to reference process items.
Type of values to process.

remarks.para: This class acts as a strongly-typed sorted dictionary of objects to be processed.
Consumers are expected to create new instances of this class through the static construction functions (e.g., , , etc.)
Note that the will not start processing until the Start method is called.
Because this represents a dictionary style collection, all keys must be unique.

Be aware that this class is based on a (i.e., a that implements ), and since items in this kind of list are automatically sorted, items will be processed in "sorted" order regardless of the order in which they are added to the list.

Important note about using an "Integer" as the key for this class: because the base class must implement IList, a normal dictionary cannot be used for the base class. IDictionary implementations do not normally implement the IList interface because of ambiguity that is caused when implementing an integer key. For example, if you implement this class with a key of type "Integer," you will not be able to access items in the by index without "casting" the as IList. This is because the Item property in both the IDictionary and IList would have the same parameters (see the class for more details.).

member.summary: Function signature that determines if a key and value can be currently processed.

remarks.para: Implementation of this function is optional. It will be assumed that an item can be processed if this function is not defined
Items must eventually get to a state where they can be processed or they will remain in the indefinitely.
Note that when this function is implemented and = ManyAtOnce (i.e., is defined), then each item presented for processing must evaluate as "CanProcessItem = True" before any items are processed.

member.summary: Defines the tempo of song as the total number of note values in one minute.

member.name: M:TVA.Media.Music.Tempo.CalculateNoteValueTime(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the actual time duration, in seconds, for the given tempo that the specified source note value will last. For example, if tempo is M.M. 120 quarter-notes per minute, then each quarter-note would last a half-second.
member.param: Relative value of note.
member.returns: Actual duration of note value in seconds.

member.name: M:TVA.Media.Music.Tempo.CalculateNoteValueTime(TVA.Media.Music.NoteValue,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates the actual time duration, in seconds, for the given tempo that the specified source note value will last. For example, if tempo is M.M. 120 quarter-notes per minute, then each quarter-note would last a half-second.
member.param: Source note value.
Total dotted note length extensions to apply.
member.returns: Actual duration of note value in seconds.

member.name: M:TVA.Media.Music.Tempo.CalculateNoteValueTime(TVA.Media.Music.NoteValueBritish,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates the actual time duration, in seconds, for the given tempo that the specified source note value will last. For example, if tempo is M.M. 120 crotchets per minute, then each crotchet would last a half-second.
member.param: Source note value.
Total dotted note length extensions to apply.
member.returns: Actual duration of note value in seconds.

member.name: P:TVA.Media.Music.Tempo.TotalNoteValues
member.summary: Total number of reference note values that occur in one minute - thus defining the tempo for a score.

member.name: P:TVA.Media.Music.Tempo.NoteValue
member.summary: Returns relative value for reference note value. For example, if tempo is M.M. 120 quarter-notes per minute, then time is referenced in quarter-notes and this function would return 0.25.

member.name: P:TVA.Media.Music.Tempo.NoteValueTime
member.summary: Total time, in seconds, for reference note value. For example, if tempo is M.M. 120 quarter-notes per minute, then time is referenced in quarter-notes and this function would return 0.5 seconds.

member.name: P:TVA.Media.Music.Tempo.NamedNoteValue
member.summary: Get or sets the note value, expressed in American form, representing the length of the note.

member.name: P:TVA.Media.Music.Tempo.NamedNoteValueBritish
member.summary: Get or sets the note value, expressed in British form, representing the length of the note.
